In 1929, Charles Ponzi devised a scheme to defraud investors by promising unusually high returns on their investments. He claimed that he could double their money in just 45 days through investments in an international postal reply coupon scheme. In reality, Ponzi used money from new investors to pay off earlier investors, creating the illusion of profitability and generating a wave of interest in his scheme. This became known as the Ponzi scheme and is still used today to defraud people out of their money.
